body_text.text: Remains of large-bodied, herbivorous hadrosaurian ornithischians are the most abundant vertebrate macrofossils in latest Cretaceous terrestrial strata of North America (Lull and Wright, 1942; Horner et al., 2004) , and have figured prominently in discussions of diversity, biogeography, and provinciality in the terminal Cretaceous (Lehman, 1987 (Lehman, , 1997 (Lehman, , 2001 Williamson, 2000; Lucas, 2003, 2006) . Hadrosaur fossils have been collected in abundance from Big Bend National Park, Texas (herein 'Big Bend'; Davies, 1983; Lehman, 1985; Wagner, 2001 ). Davies (1983) applied unpublished observations on postcranial variation (Brett-Surman, 1975) to conclude that two hadrosaur species were present in Campanian strata of the Aguja Formation, Kritosaurus cf. K. navajovius and an indeterminate lambeosaurine. Although significant new hadrosaur material has been recovered since Davies' work, only preliminary observations have been published (Davies and Lehman, 1989; Wagner and Lehman, 1999, 2001; Wagner, 2001 ). The hadrosaurs of Big Bend have yet to contribute significantly to debates on latest Cretaceous faunal dynamics due to the paucity of skull material, upon which most hadrosaur taxonomy is based.

This report constitutes the first published description of a hadrosaur from Big Bend. Although the specimen consists solely of a left maxilla, it represents the most morphologically distinct new Campanian hadrosaur reported from North America in over two decades (Horner, 1982 (Horner, , 1983 . This new species confirms Davies' conclusion, and has implications for provinciality and endemism in the Campanian of North America.

Institutional Abbreviations-AMNH, American Museum of Natural History, New York; BMNH, the Natural History Museum, London; CMN, Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa; MOR, Museum of the Rockies, Bozeman; NMMNH, New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science, Albuquerque; ROM, Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto; TMM, Texas Memorial Museum Vertebrate Paleontology Laboratory, Austin.

Stratigraphy-We follow the model of Late Cretaceous stratigraphy and tectonic history of Trans-Pecos Texas of Lehman (1985 Lehman ( , 1988 Lehman ( , 1991 Bohanan, 1987; Macon, 1994) . Site TMM 43681 lies in the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation, just below the contact with the overlying the Javelina Formation (Fig. 1) . The upper shale member consists of interbedded mudstone and sandstone representing interdistributary bay, coastal marsh and swamp, distributary channel and coastal and inland floodplain facies recording the terrestrial component of the final regression of the Cretaceous epeiric sea in west Texas. Pyroclastic deposits in the upper shale member approximately 3 km south of TMM 43681 have yielded a preliminary U-Pb isotopic age of 76.9 AE 1.2 Ma (Befus et al., 2008) , while ashes some 30 km northeast indicated an age of 72.6 AE 1.5 Ma (Breyer et al., 2007) . TMM 43681 is at a level comparable to the former datum, suggesting that 76.6 Ma is a reasonable approximation of the site's age. The specimen is thus Middle Campanian (Ogg et al., 2004) , or early Judithian, in age, corroborated by biostratigraphic studies (Lehman, 1985; Rowe et al., 1992; Sankey, 2001; Cifelli, 1994; Waggoner, 2006) .

Taphonomy-Site TMM 43681 lies within a dark grey mudstone just below a chaotically-bedded very fine sandstone with undulose contacts (Fig. 1 ). These are part of a sequence of inclined, arrhythmic heterolithic strata (Wood et al., 1988) within an interval of relatively sandy coastal plain facies rock (Lehman, 1985) . This unit contains reworked ferruginous concretions, carbonaceous plant fragments, abraded fossil bone, and unionid bivalve fragments, and has been interpreted as a small tributary channel deposit (Wagner, 2001) .

Along with the maxilla described below, rib fragments, a middle caudal-and a distal caudal vertebral centrum, a fragmentary caudal neural arch, a chevron with an unroofed haemal canal, and a ziphodont archosaur tooth were also recovered. All but the latter are hadrosaurian, but are not diagnostic, and we consider them Hadrosauria incertae sedis. All of the bones are roughly cylindrical; they probably exhibited similar hydrodynamic behavior and would have been easily transported by current action (Voorhies, 1969; Behrensmeyer, 1975; Shipman, 1981) . Since all are abraded, and they represent one or more very incomplete skeletons, we believe they were transported after disarticulation. Transport distance would have been limited by the small size of the stream drainage, and it is therefore likely that surrounding coastal plain facies rocks represent the environment in which the animal died.
HADROSAURIA von Huene, 1956 HADROSAURIDAE Cope, 1870 LAMBEOSAURINAE Parks, 1923 ANGULOMASTACATOR new genus Type Species-Angulomastacator daviesi, by original designation in hoc loco.

Etymology-Angulus, -i (Latin), 'corner, angle,' in reference both to the unusual morphology of the maxilla and the Big Bend of the Rio Grande; mastax, -akoB (Greek) 'jaw, mouth,' and '-tor' (Latin) signifying agency; preferred translation 'bend chewer.'
Diagnosis-As for type and only species.
Holotype-TMM 43681-1, incomplete left maxilla. Occurrence-Locality TMM 43681, near Dawson Creek, upper shale member, Aguja Formation; precise locality information on file at the TMM.

Etymology-For Kyle L. Davies, first to suggest the presence of a lambeosaurine in the Aguja Formation, in recognition of his significant contribution to the study of the hadrosaurs of Big Bend, and in gratitude for his generous assistance to both authors in their work.

Diagnosis-Differs from all other hadrosaurs in possession of abrupt 45 ventral deflection of anterior maxilla and occlusal plane such that occlusal surfaces of mesial teeth are well ventral to distal teeth in articulation.

Description-Maxilla TMM 43681-1 (Fig. 2) is clearly hadrosaurid, but is incomplete and poorly preserved. The extreme anterior tip, much of the dorsal margin including the dorsal process, and most of the maxillary parapet (Norman, 1980) are missing. As preserved the bone is hemicylindrical, with a relatively planar medial surface, and measures 29 cm long anteroposteriorly, 9.2 cm high dorsoventrally, and 6.2 cm thick mediolaterally at the jugal process. Surficial bone is abraded and "limonitized," rendered friable and discolored.

The anteroventral margin of the maxilla and the occlusal plane of the maxillary dentition are steeply deflected ventrally from a point anterior to the base of the dorsal process, giving the bone a 'boomerang' shape in lateral view. The specimen was broken at the point of strongest ventral inflection, but the parts fit together securely, the tooth files are parallel, and the grain of the bone is continuous across the break, so its shape is not an artifact of preparation. Had it been the result of distortion dur-ing sediment compaction, the element would have had to rest upright on its alveolar margin prior to burial, yet it was found in a flat-lying, dynamically stable position. Further, had it been deformed, the vertical tooth files would diverge significantly at the point of maximum flexion or would themselves be curved, yet they are straight and diverge only enough to maintain a continuous occlusal surface. There is no sign of anomalous dental wear or any other pathology, so we accept this as the normal morphology of the species.

Some illustrations show a similar, more subtle concavity of the maxilla in hadrosaurids (Lambe, 1914; Gilmore, 1924a; Sternberg, 1935) , but this is usually attributable to curvature of the buccal fossa carried into the vertical plane by photographic angle or rotation of the maxilla about its long axis. There is a mild ventral deflection of the anterior maxilla in some hadrosaurids, approximately 15 in Hypacrosaurus altispinus (Gilmore, 1924b) , 18 in Prosaurolophus blackfeetensis (Horner, 1992) , 25 in both Brachylophosaurus canadiensis (Prieto-Má rquez, 2005) and Lambeosaurus magnicristatus (Evans and Reisz, 2007) , and 5 -18 in Parasaurolophus tubicen (Wiman, 1931; Sullivan and Williamson, 1999) . None is as steep as the 45 observed in TMM 43681-1 (Fig. 2) , and none have the occlusal plane likewise deflected.

The premaxillary articulation of TMM 43681-1 is a distinct, anterodorsolaterally oriented subrectangular shelf ('maxillary shelf' of Horner, 1990) extending from the anterior terminus to the anterior maxillary foramen. In lateral view it is angled approximately 45 from the horizontal, subparallel to the deflected alveolar margin. This is steeper than in most hadrosaurs, but is most similar to Aralosaurus tuberiferus (Rozhdestvensky, 1968; Godefroit et al., 2004) , Kritosaurus (Brown, 1910; Lambe, 1914; Parks, 1919; Horner, 1992; Gates and Sampson, 2007) , and Parasaurolophus (Parks, 1922; Wiman, 1931; Sullivan and Williamson, 1999) . The edge of the shelf is sharp anteriorly, projecting approximately 2.5 cm lateral and ventral to the toothrow and obscuring the mesial-most teeth in lateral view. The joint surface bears two parasagittally elongate, shallow, dish-like fossae that accepted slight swellings on the premaxilla, forming the hillock-and-dish articulation of lambeosaurines (Parks, 1923) and Edmontosaurus (Fig 3C) .

The dorsomedial edge of the anterior maxilla preserves the base of the medial flange (Horner, 1990 ), which appears too thin to support a palatal process ('anterodorsal process' of Horner, 1988 Horner, , 1990 Horner, , 1992 'rostrodorsal process' of Head, 1998) . It is wide-ly held that presence of this process versus a 'maxillary shelf' allows discrimination of 'hadrosaurines' from lambeosaurines (respectively; Horner, 1990; Kirkland, 1998; Head, 1998; Horner et al., 2004) . The palatal process is ancestral for Archosauria, and its presence is not positive evidence of any relationship (Wagner, 2001) , although its absence diagnoses Lambeosaurinae (Horner, 1990 (Horner, , 1992 . A nearly rectangular, dorsolaterally oriented premaxillary scarf facet for the premaxilla, or 'maxillary shelf,' is not restricted to Lambeosaurinae; it is present to some extent in Edmontosaurus (Fig. 3C) alongside a well-developed palatal process. However, it is much better developed in lambeosaurines and the specimen described here.

TMM 43681-1 is incomplete dorsally, exposing the cylindrical maxillary neurovascular canal, which opens anteriorly through the poorly preserved anterior maxillary foramen (Fig. 2C , Davies, 1983; Wagner, 2001 ). This foramen lies just anteroventral to the base of the dorsal process as in hadrosaurids; it FIGURE 3. Comparison of maxillae of hadrosaurids, with selected articular surfaces labeled. A, Kritosaurus cf. K. navajovius, AMNH 3079 (reversed); B, Brachylophosaurus canadiensis MOR 1071-7-6-98-79 (reversed); C, Edmontosaurus regalis CMN 2289 (no scale bar); D, Angulomastacator daviesi, n. gen n. sp., TMM 43681-1; E, Corythosaurus casuarius, CMN 8676 (reversed); F, Hypacrosaurus altispinus ROM 702; G, Parasaurolophus tubicen NMMNH P-25100. Note that E-G have the ectopterygoid attached. Abbreviations: dt, dorsal jugal tubercle; g, groove for ridge on anterior jugal process; j, jugal articular surface; la, lacrimal facet; pm, premaxillary articulation; u, jugal facet of dorsal process; vt, ventral jugal tubercle. Scale bars equal 5 cm.

opened anteriorly onto the premaxillary facet, and was partly or completely obscured by the premaxilla in articulation as in lambeosaurines and Edmontosaurus (Wagner, 2001) . The peribuccal foramina arc dorsally from the base of the jugal facet as in Hadrosauridae (Davies, 1983; Wagner, 2001 ), but do not wrap tightly around the latter as in Edmontosaurus (Lambe, 1917) and Parasaurolophus (Sullivan and Williamson, 1999) .

Posteromedial to the base of the dorsal process, the abraded stump of the palatine articulation is steeply inclined posteroventrally toward the ectopterygoid shelf, as in lambeosaurines. As in other hadrosaurids, the shelf itself is long, and does not ramp down to the distal alveolar margin. Its lateral edge is damaged where it thins posterior to the jugal process, but it clearly contacted the latter as in hadrosaurids, and was not separated from it by a longitudinal sulcus (Wagner, 2001; Prieto-Má rquez, Gaete et al., 2006) .

The jugal process is incomplete dorsally, but was clearly an expanded, striated boss as in Hadrosauridae. The ventral extremity of the process is set well dorsal to the lateral margin of the ectopterygoid shelf, and the latter must have curved dorsally to meet it as in some lambeosaurines. Dorsal to this, the low 'ventral tubercle' of the jugal articulation is significantly anterior to the 'dorsal tubercle' as in lambeosaurines (Wagner, 2001) , and possibly Brachylophosaurus canadiensis (Fig 3; Wagner, pers. obs.) .

Internal molds of the 'special foramina' (Edmund, 1957 ) form a shallow arc slightly ventral to, and paralleling, the dorsomedial edge on the medial face of the bone. Below these, loss of the maxillary parapet has exposed the typically hadrosaurid maxillary dentition, tightly packed into an estimated 48 interlocking vertical tooth files. Each file holds two or three replacement teeth dorsal to one or two functional teeth that contribute to a common, buccoventrally-inclined occlusal surface. Individual teeth bear a single longitudinal carina on the enameled buccal face of their mesiodistally narrow, lozenge-shaped crowns. Neither the shape of the carina, nor the presence of serrations or papillae can be discerned.

Affinities-The unusual pendant anterior maxillary process of Angulomastacator daviesi distinguishes it from all other hadrosaurids; the 'anteroventral process' of authors (Horner, 1990 (Horner, , 1992 Head, 1998) is simply that part of the dentigerous maxilla anterior to the dorsal process and ventral to the palatal process, and is not pendant. Some non-hadrosaurid hadrosaurs have a true, pendant, edentulous anteroventral process (Kirkland, 1998; Head, 1998; You et al., 2003; Wagner, pers. obs.) , and Shuangmiaosaurus gilmorei (You et al., 2003) even has a 'boomerang shaped' maxilla. However, A. daviesi is clearly a hadrosaurid, and the possibility of a close relationship with any of these can be safely discounted.

In A. daviesi, the premaxillary articulation is extensive and shelf-like, with pronounced hillock-and-dish structures, the palatine process is steeply inclined, the jugal facet is elevated above the level of the ectopterygoid shelf, the dorsal jugal tubercle is posterior to the ventral, and the anterior maxillary foramen was probably obscured in lateral view in articulation. This combination of characters is elsewhere found only in Lambeosaurinae, and we therefore refer A. daviesi to that clade. Its relationships to other lambeosaurines are unclear, and assignment to an established genus would be misleading and likely incorrect, so we feel justified in erecting a new genus to receive this species (International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, 1999).

Biogeographic Implications-The presence of Angulomastacator daviesi in the Aguja Formation fits the hypothesis of endemism and provinciality in latest Cretaceous North America (Lehman, 1987 (Lehman, , 1997 (Lehman, , 2001 better than the recently proposed alternative that differences among Campanian faunas are an art-ifact of comparing asynchronous, pancontinental faunas Lucas, 2003, 2006) . Although the precise age relationships have not been established, A. daviesi must have been contemporaneous with some part of faunas from well-prospected, continuous sections elsewhere, including the Judith River Group of Alberta (Eberth, 2005) , and the Two Medicine Formation of Montana (Rogers et al., 1993) . The maxilla of A. daviesi (and probably the dentary as well) is so distinctive that we feel it would have been collected and reported had it been found anywhere. We therefore accept the absence of evidence for Angulomastacator daviesi at other locations as evidence that it is indeed absent. In fact, all Aguja dinosaur species known from material other than teeth are either endemic (Lehman, 1989; Wagner and Lehman, 1999, 2001; Wagner, 2001, pers. obs.) , poorly known (Wagner and Lehman, 1999, 2001; Wagner, 2001, pers. obs.; Sankey, 2001) , or inadequately studied (Carpenter, 1990 ). The only valid confirmation that the Aguja fauna is not wholly endemic, and therefore suggestive of provincialism, would be positive evidence of Aguja taxa elsewhere. No such evidence has yet been presented.

back_matter.text: This work was completed in partial fulfillment of the requirements for a Master's Degree for JRW in the Department of Geosciences at Texas Tech University, and the authors are grateful to committee members J. Barrick and S. Chatterjee. We thank S. Chapman, D. Goujet, P. Holroyd, W. Langston, Jr., P. Owen, K. Padian, T. Rowe, J. Schiebout, and W. Simpson for access to specimen in their care. For assistance with illustrations, we thank J. Dodd, A. Prieto-Márquez, J. Rodgers, and J. Sprinkle. Field assistance was provided by J. Anglen, R. Ashmore, A. Coulson, T. King, R. Kissel, T. Walsh, S. Wick, and J. Browning, who discovered TMM 43681-1. We thank R. Holmes, A. Prieto-Márquez, and an anonymous reviewer for their help in improving this paper. Financial assistance was provided by the Departments of Geosciences and Civil Engineering at TTU, the Science Department at South Plains College, the Graduate School at TTU, Sigma Xi National Scientific Honorary, the Jackson School of Geological Sciences at the University of Texas at Austin, and an NSF IGERT grant to the Center for Computational Biology and Bioinformatics at UT Austin. We are indebted to the Science and Resource Management staff at Big Bend National Park, and the National Park Service, for their assistance in permitting issues and their continued support of our work in Big Bend.

FIGREF0.text: LAMBEOSAURINE HADROSAUR (REPTILIA: DINOSAURIA) FROM THE UPPER SHALE MEMBER OF THE CAMPANIAN AGUJA FORMATION OF TRANS-PECOS TEXAS JONATHAN R. WAGNER * and THOMAS M. LEHMAN; Department of Geosciences, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, Texas 79409-1053, U.S.A.

FIGREF1.text: Stratigraphic column measured at locality TMM 43681. Inset map shows the location of Big Bend National Park within Texas, and the location of site TMM 43681 within the park. Major roads are indicated as dashed lines, black square indicates park headquarters at Panther Junction.

FIGREF2.text: Left maxilla TMM 43681-1, holotype of Angulomastacator daviesi, coated with ammonium chloride. A, lateral view; B, anterior portion in lateral view, showing hillock-and-dish structure; C, medial view; D, dorsal view; E, reconstruction of the specimen, gray areas indicate unrecovered portions. Photographs a-d are orthogonal to the bone as it would lie in articulation, the shape of the element differs slightly from its appearance when laid flat. Scale bar equals 10 cm; smaller scale bar for E only.
